title: An extrafollicular pathway for the generation of effector CD8<sup>+</sup> T cells driven by the proinflammatory cytokine, IL-12
abstract: The proinflammatory cytokine IL-12 drives the generation of terminally differentiated KLRG1<sup>+</sup> effector CD8<sup>+</sup> T cells. Using a <italic>Toxoplasma</italic> vaccination model, we delineate the sequence of events that naïve CD8<sup>+</sup> T cells undergo to become terminal effectors and the differentiation steps controlled by IL-12. We demonstrate that direct IL-12 signaling on CD8<sup>+</sup> T cells is essential for the induction of KLRG1 and IFN-γ, but the subsequent downregulation of CXCR3 is controlled by IL-12 indirectly through the actions of IFN-γ and IFN-γ-inducible chemokines. Differentiation of nascent effectors occurs in an extrafollicular splenic compartment and is driven by late IL-12 production by DCs distinct from the classical CD8α<sup>+</sup> DC. Unexpectedly, we also found extensive proliferation of both KLRG1<sup>−</sup> and KLRG1<sup>+</sup> CD8<sup>+</sup> T cells in the marginal zone and red pulp, which ceases prior to the final KLRG1<sup>Hi</sup> CXCR3<sup>Lo</sup> stage. Our findings highlight the notion of an extrafollicular pathway for effector T cell generation.
